titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Tazewell M. Howard Letters, 1855-1865
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, November 2021

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Letters from Howard to a younger brother who was a medical student in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, containing brief references to the Know-Nothing Party, secession, and a rumor that Governor Henry A. Wise of Virginia had been murdered by abolitionists; and Civil War letters of Dr. T.H. Howard and H.L. Honnell from Georgia, Kentucky and Mississippi.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Tazewell M. Howard letters, 1855-1865, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, November 2021.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Tazewell M. Howard was a physician, from Campbelltown (Fulton County), Georgia.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Letters from Howard to a younger brother who was a medical student in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, containing brief references to the Know-Nothing Party, secession, and a rumor that Governor Henry A. Wise of Virginia had been murdered by abolitionists; and Civil War letters of Dr. T.H. Howard and H.L. Honnell from Georgia, Kentucky and Mississippi.
